bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to E.J. Scannell, June 11, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] discusses Scannell's work against yellow fever in Chiapas, Mexico.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to E.J. Scannell, June 11, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
, D. C.
June 11, 1922.
Dear Scannell:
div1.p:
I was glad to get your letter and charts showing your work at
Chiapas.

Right was the plan to take Tapachula--a key-point--and free it
from Stegomyia whether it was infected or not. That is the method of
handling a regional focus.

I am somewhat surprised at your deep well breeding and yet I
need not have been, as King, of San Juan, P. R., found them breeding in
cisterns to which they had no access save by a 16 ft. rain spout and
I, myself, saw them breeding in a well with a plank top in a cellar
in Bahia, Brazil.
I would like to know, however, three things:

First of all, how did you you know they were breeding in your
wells? Did you draw larvae out, or judge by mosquitoes coming out
of them? In the latter case, of course, they may have been just
sheltering in them.

2/ What was the width of your wells and--more of less--the
temperature of the water?

3. How can you tell whether your fish in the wells are alive or
not?

One thing you can depend on in the small and moderate sized towns:
They will free themselves from yellow fever by failure of the human
host if they have a reasonable chance to do so: If the large towns
and other key-points are controlled--unless there is susceptible im-
im-
/2
migration your problem is solved.

Do you know how White found your address? He was at my house
the day after Xmas and we had just received a Xmas card from yourself
and Mrs. Scannell and the post mark gave me your address. That is
one advantage of Xmas cards I have not seen exploited! By the way,
Laura, who is typing this, would like to have Mrs. Scannell's pres-
ent address as she has finally succeeded in getting a volume of her
poems for “the Scannells,” including “Sonny.” Her delay in so doing
was owing to the fact of the first edition being exhausted very
quickly and there being a long delay, owing to strikes etc. before
the appearance of the second. I consider it a good book.
With very best remembrances from us both, I remain
